conclusion.title: Gist of Combinations of Functions
conclusion.p: In this lesson, we learned to combine functions graphically, numerically, and with formulas. However, you most likely have been combining functions at some level your whole life.
Combining functions means to perform arithmetic operations on the outputs of two or more functions, such as:

li.p: The ouputs of two functions are added together.
The ouputs of two functions are divided.

conclusion.p: Note that this is different from the composition of functions (lesson 08), where the output of one function was used as the input of another function.

Typical combinations in this course are adding/subtracting and multiplying/dividing functions, though any operation on two or more numbers would correspond to a function combination, f(x)^{\displaystyle{g(x)}} being one example.
A simple example of the combination of functions is that of Profit, Revenue and Cost.

example.p: It costs money to manufacture a product, and you can make money by selling it. The profit is the difference between how much money you collect from selling the product, and how much it cost to manufacture it.

Let C(u) be the cost, in thousands of dollars, of manufacturing u tons of a product. Let R(u) be the revenue, in thousands of dollars, collected through selling u tons of the product. Finally, P(u) is the profit, in thousands of dollars, from making and selling u tons of the product.
Using function notation, we would write:P(u) = R(u) - C(u)
Work through the following example of this concept.

statement.p: In this problem, remember that Profit = Revenue - Cost, or in function notation:P(u) = R(u) - C(u)

The graph below shows the cost function C(u) and the revenue function R(u). Sliding the given point along the graph of C(u) will also move points on the graphs of R(u) and P(u), all with the same input values.
